entries.definition: The first letter of the English and of many other alphabets. Then   capital A of the alphabets of Middle and Western Europe, as also then   small letter (a), besides the forms in Italic, black letter, etc., aren   all descended from the old Latin A, which was borrowed from the Greekn   Alpha, of the same form; and this was made from the first letter (/) ofn   the Phoenician alphabet, the equivalent of the Hebrew Aleph, and itselfn   from the Egyptian origin. The Aleph was a consonant letter, with an   guttural breath sound that was not an element of Greek articulation;n   and the Greeks took it to represent their vowel Alpha with the a sound,n   the Phoenician alphabet having no vowel symbols.

The name of the sixth tone in the model major scale (that in C),n   or the first tone of the minor scale, which is named after it the scalen   in A minor. The second string of the violin is tuned to the A in then   treble staff. -- A sharp (A/) is the name of a musical tonen   intermediate between A and B. -- A flat (A/) is the name of a tonen   intermediate between A and G.
An adjective, commonly called the indefinite article, andn   signifying one or any, but less emphatically.
In each; to or for each; as, "twenty leagues a day", "a hundredn   pounds a year", "a dollar a yard", etc.

In process of; in the act of; into; to; -- used with verbaln   substantives in -ing which begin with a consonant. This is a shortenedn   form of the preposition an (which was used before the vowel sound); asn   in a hunting, a building, a begging.
A barbarous corruption of have, of he, and sometimes of it and ofn   they.
An expletive, void of sense, to fill up the meter

A, as a prefix to English words, is derived from various sources.n   (1) It frequently signifies on or in (from an, a forms of AS. on),n   denoting a state, as in afoot, on foot, abed, amiss, asleep, aground,n   aloft, away (AS. onweg), and analogically, ablaze, atremble, etc. (2)n   AS. of off, from, as in adown (AS. ofd/ne off the dun or hill). (3) AS.n   a- (Goth. us-, ur-, Ger. er-), usually giving an intensive force, andn   sometimes the sense of away, on, back, as in arise, abide, ago. (4) Oldn   English y- or i- (corrupted from the AS. inseparable particle ge-,n   cognate with OHG. ga-, gi-, Goth. ga-), which, as a prefix, made non   essential addition to the meaning, as in aware. (5) French a (L. adn   to), as in abase, achieve. (6) L. a, ab, abs, from, as in avert. (7)n   Greek insep. prefix / without, or privative, not, as in abyss, atheist;n   akin to E. un-.
A registry mark given by underwriters (as at Lloyd's) to shipsn   in first-class condition. Inferior grades are indicated by A 2 and A 3.
